data.title: Green Bay’s ‘one of a kind’ Keisean Nixon named first-team All-Pro at kick returner for second straight season
data.meta_description: Packers kick returner Keisean Nixon is now a two-time selection as first-team All-Pro by the Associated Press.
data.text:
Since the turn of the century, the list of Green Bay Packers players who have been named first-team All-Pro twice includes Aaron Rodgers, Davante Adams, Charles Woodson, David Bakhtiari … and Keisean Nixon.

Nixon was named to the first team by the Associated Press as kick returner, following up the same honor bestowed to him by the National Football League Players Association one day earlier. It also marks a second straight year that he's earned the honor.

Nixon led the league with 26.1 yards per return in 2023, racking up 782 yards over 30 returns. Last year, he returned 35 kicks for 1,009 yards (28.8 per return), including a 105-yard touchdown.

“It’s a big deal,” Nixon said Thursday when asked about the NFLPA honor, though he also indicated he was waiting for the AP vote.

When asked if a player like him was an endangered species as the NFL implements rules that curtail kickoff returns, he said with a smile, “Am I an endangered species? I’m one of a kind.”

On Friday, Nixon said it was a satisfying development after he felt he was snubbed for a Pro Bowl roster spot.

"It shows my worth," Nixon said. "Last year was my first year ever doing (kickoffs regularly), and in my first full year I thought I was going to get the same opps (opportunities) as last year and (I got) nowhere near it. I still managed to have a good year, kind of, and it was a blessing, man. I'm happy."

Nixon will also contribute Sunday in the secondary, where the Packers will aim to slow the Dallas Cowboys in an NFC wild-card playoff battle.

The cornerback has an interception this year, with six passes defended, two fumble recoveries, three tackles for loss and 80 combined tackles.

The All-Pro team features just one player at numerous positions, including quarterback, running back, tight end, kicker, kick returner and each of the five offensive line positions. It names three receivers, two pass rushers, three linebackers, two cornerbacks, a slot corner and two safeties.

Pewaukee native T.J. Watt was named first-team All Pro for the fourth time in his career at pass rusher.

Packers first-team All-Pro selections (since 1980)

Keisean Nixon, kick returner (2022, 2023)

Aaron Rodgers (2011, 2014, 2020, 2021)

De'Vondre Campbell, linebacker (2021)

Davante Adams, wide receiver (2020, 2021)

David Bakhtiari, tackle (2018, 2020)

Corey Linsley, center (2020)

John Kuhn, fullback (2014)

Charles Woodson, defensive back (2009, 2011)

Clay Matthews, linebacker (2010)

William Henderson, fullback (2004)

Darren Sharper, defensive back (2000)

Reggie White, defensive end (1995, 1998)

Antonio Freeman, wide receiver (1998)

LeRoy Butler, defensive back (1993, 1996, 1997, 1998)

Brett Favre, quarterback (1995, 1996, 1997)

Sterling Sharpe, wide receiver (1989, 1992, 1993)

Chris Jacke, kicker (1993)

Tim Harris, linebacker (1989)

James Lofton, wide receiver (1981)

Ryan Wood contributed to this story.
